name: NPR
text:
Listen to Billie Eilish's new song "My Future." Written and recorded in Los Angeles during lockdown, it's a dreamy ode to freedom.
https://t.co/YkmEUHEGA1

name: NPR
text:
A trillion dollars worth of American farmland will change hands in the coming years — as wealthy investors increasingly buy it up.

But their decisions, from hundreds of miles away, will have serious impacts on rural communities and the environment.
https://t.co/fX4wSd4AAi

name: NPR
text: Two members of the Philadelphia Phillies staff tested positive for the coronavirus following the team’s weekend series against the Miami Marlins, who paused their season due to a COVID-19 outbreak.  https://t.co/1yHT1OUgG5

name: NPR
text:
"He believed that in all of us, there exists the capacity for great courage, that in all of us there is a longing to do what's right."

Read Barack Obama's emotional eulogy for John Lewis:
https://t.co/znlMk6TbfR

name: NPR
text:
Voters in Missouri will soon decide whether to expand eligibility for the state's Medicaid program to provide insurance to more than 230,000 additional people.

If it passes, coverage for the newly eligible would begin in 2021.
https://t.co/U75LMCayZI

name: NPR
text:
As the coronavirus surges in Mexico, low earners make up the highest share of deaths — and lack the funds to stay afloat during the deepening recession.

Now, pressure is rising on the hesitant government to offer financial help.
https://t.co/kxVSPNOQBG

name: NPR
text:
Amazon’s sales skyrocketed amid the pandemic, hitting close to $89 billion — a 40% increase from last year.

The jump in sales coincides with an economic crisis that has left many retailers struggling to survive. 
https://t.co/hdi1RQDQc6

name: NPR
text:
California has been using inmates to fight fires since the 1940s. But this summer, many were sent home because of COVID-19.

And as the state enters peak fire season, its forces are down significantly.
https://t.co/PnR1fjzVNO

name: NPR
text:
President Trump claims that Republicans hate vote-by-mail. 

But a recent poll found that half of all Republicans nationwide support allowing all registered voters access to a mail ballot.
https://t.co/7gYhQoIRjA

name: NPR
text:
Across the country, at least 100 Catholic schools will close in the fall because of the COVID-19 economic crisis.

And low-income families and students of color will be hit especially hard.
https://t.co/MYcXfAZ5Sc

name: NPR
text:
Two new studies involving monkeys suggest COVID-19 vaccine candidates can provide disease protection after a single injection — but it will take large-scale human trials to know for sure if they work.
https://t.co/I4KOFOSlw1

name: NPR
text:
A series of unusual decisions led to a private tech company winning a federal contract to gather key COVID-19 data instead of the CDC, NPR found.

The company's CEO is a longtime Republican donor with ties to Trump Organization financiers.
https://t.co/2D679CsWYG

name: NPR
text:
For the first time, scientists have modified the genes of a squid.

The success shows that cephalopods can finally be studied using the same genetic tools that let scientists explore the biology of more familiar lab animals — like mice and fruit flies.
https://t.co/PlEn3TyQVk

name: NPR
text:
"You Can't Take It with You — but evidently you can perform it forever."

From "Our Town" to "The Crucible," take a look at the most popular high school plays and musicals since the 1930s.
https://t.co/R5X7Ju92ks

name: NPR
text:
NEW: The Census Bureau is cutting short critical door-knocking efforts for the 2020 census amid growing concerns among Democrats in Congress that the White House is pressuring the bureau to wrap up counting soon for political gain, NPR has learned.
https://t.co/HU31j2DyAe

name: NPR
text:
This month marks the 30th anniversary of the Americans with Disabilities Act, considered the most important civil rights law since the 1960s.

On @throughlineNPR, we look back at how it came to be — and what the disability community is still fighting for.
https://t.co/PO0klqKz8Z

name: NPR
text:
A delay in counting mail ballots should be seen as a sign that officials are safeguarding against the sort of fraud Trump says he is worried about, says Pennsylvania's secretary of state.
https://t.co/bOoIBPQwYr

name: NPR
text:
Author Robert P. Jones examines the legacy of white supremacy among Southern Baptists and other denominations.

On social justice, he says, "White Christians have been largely silent ... and have hardly begun these conversations."
https://t.co/QjUkJQ9DKJ

name: NPR
text:
Terrorism analysts warn that far-right and anti-government agitators are either attacking protesters or trying to glom onto their cause to push their own agendas.

And with street clashes already happening, they fear the worst is yet to come.
https://t.co/HjHyVZj7nO

name: NPR
text:
HBCUs have an extra factor to consider as they decide if schools will reopen in the fall:

Black people are dying from the coronavirus at two and a half times the rate of white people. 
https://t.co/5wOWMI9VOC

name: NPR
text:
Inspired by her family, a high school senior has created a tool that predicts crop harvests to help reduce food insecurity.

"I have watched my younger siblings struggle with the lifelong effects of malnutrition," she says.
https://t.co/zXZODXCN0o

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. GDP shrank by a record 32.9% in the second quarter. But the way GDP is reported can skew impressions of the economy.

Here’s what that number really means, and how much a gauge of the future it represents. https://t.co/MV6g5L8a5T

name: NPR
text:
"Will I come out of here? Racing thoughts. A close friend has already died from COVID-19. I’m not sure I’ll ever see my husband again."

Journalist Anna King felt fine on the morning of June 3. Then a fever came — 104 degrees. (@KUOW) https://t.co/IV2LKf9nLy
